topics.name: 4.1 Atomic structure and the periodic table

subtopics.title: Atoms, elements and compounds
content: All substances are made of atoms. An atom is the smallest part of an element that can exist.
Atoms of each element are represented by a chemical symbol (eg O for oxygen, Na for sodium)
Elements are shown in the periodic table (approximately 100 different elements)
Compounds are formed from elements by chemical reactions
Chemical reactions involve formation of new substances and often have energy changes
Compounds contain two or more elements chemically combined in fixed proportions
Compounds can be represented by formulae using atomic symbols
Compounds can only be separated into elements by chemical reactions
required_skills: Use names and symbols of first 20 elements in periodic table
Use names and symbols of elements in Groups 1 and 7
Name compounds from given formulae or symbol equations
Write word equations for specification reactions
Write formulae and balanced chemical equations
(HT only) Write balanced half equations and ionic equations

subtopics.title: Mixtures
content: A mixture consists of two or more elements or compounds not chemically combined
Mixtures can be separated by physical processes: filtration, crystallisation, distillation, chromatography
Paper chromatography separates mixtures based on different solubilities
RF values in chromatography can be calculated
Pure substances melt and boil at specific temperatures
Pure substances produce sharp melting/boiling point graphs
required_skills: Calculate RF values from chromatography results
Interpret melting point and boiling point data for purity
Design suitable separation techniques based on substance properties
mathematical_skills: Plot and interpret melting/boiling point graphs

topics.name: 4.2 Bonding, structure, and properties of matter

subtopics.title: Chemical bonds
content: There are three types of chemical bonds: ionic, covalent and metallic
Ionic bonding occurs between metals and non-metals
Ionic bonds involve transfer of electrons forming oppositely charged ions
Covalent bonding occurs between non-metals
Covalent bonds involve sharing of electron pairs
Metallic bonding occurs between metal atoms
Metallic bonds involve delocalised electrons
required_skills: Draw dot and cross diagrams for ionic compounds
Draw dot and cross diagrams for simple covalent molecules
Explain properties of substances based on bonding
(HT only) Work out the charge on ions of elements in Groups 1, 2 and 7
mathematical_skills: Work with charges in ionic compounds
Calculate numbers of electrons involved in bonding

subtopics.title: Conservation of mass and balanced equations
content: Law of conservation of mass states mass is not created or destroyed in chemical reactions
Mass of products equals mass of reactants in closed system
Balanced equations show equal numbers of atoms of each element on both sides
Relative formula mass (Mr) is sum of relative atomic masses of atoms in formula
(HT only) Moles relate mass of substance to relative formula mass
required_skills: (HT only) Calculate moles from mass and Mr
(HT only) Calculate reacting masses using moles
mathematical_skills: (HT only) Use ratios in reacting mass calculations
